case_vignette: A 23-year-old female presents to urgent clinic with complaints of sunburn. Patient endorses history of traveling to the beach a week ago and did not apply any sunblock. She endorses fevers, but review of systems is otherwise negative. She noticed a facial rash a few days ago that feels warm to touch on the face. Family history is remarkable for similar rash in her mother. She does not take any medications. Physical examination of the face reveals bright pink thin plaques on the bilateral cheeks exending onto the nasal bridge but sparing the nasolabial folds bilaterally.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. I got a sunburn and now I have a fever and a warm rash on my face.

No, I haven't had any of those symptoms.

My mom had a similar rash, but I haven't had any skin conditions.
Have you taken any medications or supplements recently?
No, I haven't taken any medications or supplements.
Have you had any allergies or reactions to medications in the past?
No, I haven't had any allergies or reactions to medications.
Have you had any family history of skin cancer or other skin conditions?
My family history is remarkable for a similar rash in my mother.
Final Diagnosis: Sunburn with associated rash and fever.
